verses.text: They also maintain that God's grace, which is given through the faith of Jesus Christ, and which is neither the law nor nature, avails only for the remission of sins that have been committed, and not for the shunning of future ones, or the subjugation of those which are now assailing us.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 26:4
verses.text: Now if all this were true, surely after offering the petition of the Lord's Prayer, "Forgive us our debts, as we forgive our debtors," we could hardly go on and say, "And lead us not into temptation".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 26:5
verses.text: The former petition we present that our sins may be forgiven; the latter, that they may be avoided or subdued,—a favour which we should by no means beg of our Father who is in heaven if we were able to accomplish it by the virtue of our human will.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 26:6
verses.text: Now I strongly advise and earnestly require your Love to read attentively the book of the blessed Cyprian which he wrote On the Lord's Prayer.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 26:7
verses.text: As far as the Lord shall assist you, understand it, and commit it to memory.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 26:8
verses.text: In this work you will see how he so appeals to the free will of those whom he edifies in his treatise, as to show them, that whatever they have to fulfil in the law, they must ask for in the prayer.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 26:9
verses.text: But this, of course, would be utterly empty if the human will were sufficient for the performance without the help of God.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 27

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 27:1
verses.text: Chapter 27 (XIV.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 27:2
verses.text: )—Grace Effects the Fulfilment of the Law, the Deliverance of Nature, and the Suppression of Sin's Dominion.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 27:3
verses.text: It has, however, been shown to demonstration that instead of really maintaining free will, they have only inflated a theory of it, which, having no stability, has fallen to the ground.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 27:4
verses.text: Neither the knowledge of God's law, nor nature, nor the mere remission of sins is that grace which is given to us through our Lord Jesus Christ; but it is this very grace which accomplishes the fulfilment of the law, and the liberation of nature, and the removal of the dominion of sin.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 27:5
verses.text: Being, therefore, convicted on these points, they resort to another expedient, and endeavour to show in some way or other that the grace of God is given us according to our merits.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 27:6
verses.text: For they say: "Granted that it is not given to us according to the merits of good works, inasmuch as it is through it that we do any good thing, still it is given to us according to the merits of a good will; for," say they, "the good will of him who prays precedes his prayer, even as the will of the believer preceded his faith, so that according to these merits the grace of God who hears, follows".

chapters.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 28

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 28:1
verses.text: Chapter 28.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 28:2
verses.text: —Faith is the Gift of God.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 28:3
verses.text: I have already discussed the point concerning faith, that is, concerning the will of him who believes, even so far as to show that it appertains to grace,—so that the apostle did not tell us, "I have obtained mercy because I was faithful;" but he said, "I have obtained mercy in order to be faithful".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 28:4
verses.text: And there are many other passages of similar import,—among them that in which he bids us "think soberly, according as God hath dealt out to every man the proportion of faith;" and that which I have already quoted: "By grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves; it is the gift of God;" and again another in the same Epistle to the Ephesians: "Peace be to the brethren, and love with faith, from God the Father, and the Lord Jesus Christ;" and to the same effect that passage in which he says, "For unto you it is given in the behalf of Christ not only to believe on Him, but also to suffer for His sake".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 28:5
verses.text: Both alike are therefore due to the grace of God,—the faith of those who believe, and the patience of those who suffer, because the apostle spoke of both as given.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 28:6
verses.text: Then, again, there is the passage, especially noticeable, in which he says, "We, having the same spirit of faith," for his phrase is not "the knowledge of faith," but "the spirit of faith;" and he expressed himself thus in order that we might understand how that faith is given to us, even when it is not sought, so that other blessings may be granted to it at its request.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 28:7
verses.text: For "how," says he, "shall they call upon Him in whom they have not believed?" The spirit of grace, therefore, causes us to have faith, in order that through faith we may, on praying for it, obtain the ability to do what we are commanded.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 28:8
verses.text: On this account the apostle himself constantly puts faith before the law; since we are not able to do what the law commands unless we obtain the strength to do it by the prayer of faith.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 29

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 29:1
verses.text: Chapter 29.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 29:2
verses.text: —God is Able to Convert Opposing Wills, and to Take Away from the Heart Its Hardness.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 29:3
verses.text: Now if faith is simply of free will, and is not given by God, why do we pray for those who will not believe, that they may believe? This it would be absolutely useless to do, unless we believe, with perfect propriety, that Almighty God is able to turn to belief wills that are perverse and opposed to faith.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 29:4
verses.text: Man's free will is addressed when it is said, "Today, if ye will hear His voice, harden not your hearts".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 29:5
verses.text: But if God were not able to remove from the human heart even its obstinacy and hardness, He would not say, through the prophet, "I will take from them their heart of stone, and will give them a heart of flesh".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 29:6
verses.text: That all this was foretold in reference to the New Testament is shown clearly enough by the apostle when he says, "Ye are our epistle,.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 29:7
verses.text: written not with ink, but with the Spirit of the living God; not in tables of stone, but in fleshly tables of the heart".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 29:8
verses.text: We must not, of course, suppose that such a phrase as this is used as if those might live in a fleshly way who ought to live spiritually; but inasmuch as a stone has no feeling, with which man's hard heart is compared, what was there left Him to compare man's intelligent heart with but the flesh, which possesses feeling? For this is what is said by the prophet Ezekiel: "I will give them another heart, and I will put a new spirit within you; and I will take the stony heart out of their flesh, and will give them a heart of flesh; that they may walk in my statutes, and keep mine ordinances, and do them: and they shall be my people, and I will be their God, saith the Lord".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 29:9
verses.text: Now can we possibly, without extreme absurdity, maintain that there previously existed in any man the good merit of a good will, to entitle him to the removal of his stony heart, when all the while this very heart of stone signifies nothing else than a will of the hardest kind and such as is absolutely inflexible against God? For where a good will precedes, there is, of course, no longer a heart of stone.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 30

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 30:1
verses.text: Chapter 30.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 30:2
verses.text: —The Grace by Which the Stony Heart is Removed is Not Preceded by Good Deserts, But by Evil Ones.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 30:3
verses.text: In another passage, also, by the same prophet, God, in the clearest language, shows us that it is not owing to any good merits on the part of men, but for His own name's sake, that He does these things.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 30:4
verses.text: This is His language: "This I do, O house of Israel, but for mine holy name's sake, which ye have profaned among the heathen, whither ye went.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 30:5
verses.text: And I will sanctify my great name, which was profaned among the heathen, which ye have profaned in the midst of them; and the heathen shall know that I am the Lord, saith the Lord God, when I shall be sanctified in you before their eyes.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 30:6
verses.text: For I will take you from among the heathen, and gather you out of all countries, and will bring you into your own land.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 30:7
verses.text: Then will I sprinkle you with clean water, and ye shall be clean: from all your own filthiness, and from all your idols will I cleanse you.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 30:8
verses.text: A new heart also will I give you, and a new spirit will I put within you; and the stony heart shall be taken away out of your flesh, and I will give you a heart of flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 30:9
verses.text: And I will put my Spirit within you, and will cause you to walk in my statutes, and ye shall keep my judgments, and do them".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 30:10
verses.text: Now who is so blind as not to see, and who so stone-like as not to feel, that this grace is not given according to the merits of a good will, when the Lord declares and testifies, "It is I, O house of Israel, who do this, but for my holy name's sake"? Now why did He say "It is I that do it, but for my holy name's sake," were it not that they should not think that it was owing to their own good merits that these things were happening, as the Pelagians hesitate not unblushingly to say? But there were not only no good merits of theirs, but the Lord shows that evil ones actually preceded; for He says, "But for my holy name's sake, which ye have profaned among the heathen".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 30:11
verses.text: Who can fail to observe how dreadful is the evil of profaning the Lord's own holy name? And yet, for the sake of this very name of mine, says He, which ye have profaned, I, even I, will make you good, but not for your own sakes; and, as He adds, "I will sanctify my great name, which was profaned among the heathen, which ye have profaned in the midst of them".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 30:12
verses.text: He says that He sanctifies His name, which He had already declared to be holy.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 30:13
verses.text: Therefore, this is just what we pray for in the Lord's Prayer—"Hallowed be Thy name".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 30:14
verses.text: We ask for the hallowing among men of that which is in itself undoubtedly always holy.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 30:15
verses.text: Then it follows, "And the heathen shall know that I am the Lord, saith the Lord God, when I shall be sanctified in you".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 30:16
verses.text: Although, then, He is Himself always holy, He is, nevertheless, sanctified in those on whom He bestows His grace, by taking from them that stony heart by which they profaned the name of the Lord.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 31

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 31:1
verses.text: Chapter 31 (XV.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 31:2
verses.text: )—Free Will Has Its Function in the Heart's Conversion; But Grace Too Has Its.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 31:3
verses.text: Lest, however, it should be thought that men themselves in this matter do nothing by free will, it is said in the Psalm, "Harden not your hearts;" and in Ezekiel himself, "Cast away from you all your transgressions, which ye have impiously committed against me; and make you a new heart and a new spirit; and keep all my commandments.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 31:4
verses.text: For why will ye die, O house of Israel, saith the Lord? for I have no pleasure in the death of him that dieth, saith the Lord God: and turn ye, and live".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 31:5
verses.text: We should remember that it is He who says, "Turn ye and live," to whom it is said in prayer, "Turn us again, O God".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 31:6
verses.text: We should remember that He says, "Cast away from you all your transgressions," when it is even He who justifies the ungodly.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 31:7
verses.text: We should remember that He says, "Make you a new heart and a new spirit," who also promises, "I will give you a new heart, and a new spirit will I put within you".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 31:8
verses.text: How is it, then, that He who says, "Make you," also says, "I will give you"? Why does He command, if He is to give? Why does He give if man is to make, except it be that He gives what He commands when He helps him to obey whom He commands? There is, however, always within us a free will,—but it is not always good; for it is either free from righteousness when it serves sin,—and then it is evil,—or else it is free from sin when it serves righteousness,—and then it is good.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 31:9
verses.text: But the grace of God is always good; and by it it comes to pass that a man is of a good will, though he was before of an evil one.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 31:10
verses.text: By it also it comes to pass that the very good will, which has now begun to be, is enlarged, and made so great that it is able to fulfil the divine commandments which it shall wish, when it shall once firmly and perfectly wish.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 31:11
verses.text: This is the purport of what the Scripture says: "If thou wilt, thou shalt keep the commandments;" so that the man who wills but is not able knows that he does not yet fully will, and prays that he may have so great a will that it may suffice for keeping the commandments.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 31:12
verses.text: And thus, indeed, he receives assistance to perform what he is commanded.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 31:13
verses.text: Then is the will of use when we have ability; just as ability is also then of use when we have the will.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 31:14
verses.text: For what does it profit us if we will what we are unable to do, or else do not will what we are able to do?.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 32

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 32:1
verses.text: Chapter 32 (XVI.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 32:2
verses.text: )—In What Sense It is Rightly Said That, If We Like, We May Keep God's Commandments.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 32:3
verses.text: The Pelagians think that they know something great when they assert that "God would not command what He knew could not be done by man".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 32:4
verses.text: Who can be ignorant of this? But God commands some things which we cannot do, in order that we may know what we ought to ask of Him.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 32:5
verses.text: For this is faith itself, which obtains by prayer what the law commands.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 32:6
verses.text: He, indeed, who said, "If thou wilt, thou shalt keep the commandments," did in the same book of Ecclesiasticus afterwards say, "Who shall give a watch before my mouth, and a seal of wisdom upon my lips, that I fall not suddenly thereby, and that my tongue destroy me not".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 32:7
verses.text: Now he had certainly heard and received these commandments: "Keep thy tongue from evil, and thy lips from speaking guile".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 32:8
verses.text: Forasmuch, then, as what he said is true: "If thou wilt, thou shalt keep the commandments," why does he want a watch to be given before his mouth, like him who says in the Psalm, "Set a watch, O Lord, before my mouth"? Why is he not satisfied with God's commandment and his own will; since, if he has the will, he shall keep the commandments? How many of God's commandments are directed against pride! He is quite aware of them; if he will, he may keep them.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 32:9
verses.text: Why, therefore, does he shortly afterwards say, "O God, Father and God of my life, give me not a proud look"? The law had long ago said to him, "Thou shalt not covet;" let him then only will, and do what he is bidden, because, if he has the will, he shall keep the commandments.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 32:10
verses.text: Why, therefore, does he afterwards say, "Turn away from me concupiscence"? Against luxury, too, how many commandments has God enjoined! Let a man observe them; because, if he will, he may keep the commandments.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 32:11
verses.text: But what means that cry to God, "Let not the greediness of the belly nor lust of the flesh take hold on me!"? Now, if we were to put this question to him personally, he would very rightly answer us and say, From that prayer of mine, in which I offer this particular petition to God, you may understand in what sense I said, "If thou wilt, thou mayest keep the commandments".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 32:12
verses.text: For it is certain that we keep the commandments if we will; but because the will is prepared by the Lord, we must ask of Him for such a force of will as suffices to make us act by the willing.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 32:13
verses.text: It is certain that it is we that will when we will, but it is He who makes us will what is good, of whom it is said (as he has just now expressed it), "The will is prepared by the Lord".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 32:14
verses.text: Of the same Lord it is said, "The steps of a man are ordered by the Lord, and his way doth He will".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 32:15
verses.text: Of the same Lord again it is said, "It is God who worketh in you, even to will!" It is certain that it is we that act when we act; but it is He who makes us act, by applying efficacious powers to our will, who has said, "I will make you to walk in my statutes, and to observe my judgments, and to do them".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 32:16
verses.text: When he says, "I will make you.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 32:17
verses.text: to do them," what else does He say in fact than, "I will take away from you your heart of stone," from which used to arise your inability to act, "and I will give you a heart of flesh," in order that you may act? And what does this promise amount to but this: I will remove your hard heart, out of which you did not act, and I will give you an obedient heart, out of which you shall act? It is He who causes us to act, to whom the human suppliant says, "Set a watch, O Lord, before my mouth".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 32:18
verses.text: That is to say: Make or enable me, O Lord, to set a watch before my mouth,—a benefit which he had already obtained from God who thus described its influence: "I set a watch upon my mouth".

chapters.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 33

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 33:1
verses.text: Chapter 33 (XVII.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 33:2
verses.text: )—A Good Will May Be Small and Weak; An Ample Will, Great Love.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 33:3
verses.text: Operating and Co-operating Grace.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 33:4
verses.text: He, therefore, who wishes to do God's commandment, but is unable, already possesses a good will, but as yet a small and weak one; he will, however, become able when he shall have acquired a great and robust will.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 33:5
verses.text: When the martyrs did the great commandments which they obeyed, they acted by a great will,—that is, with great love.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 33:6
verses.text: Of this love the Lord Himself thus speaks: "Greater love hath no man than this, that a man lay down his life for his friends".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 33:7
verses.text: In accordance with this, the apostle also says, "He that loveth his neighbour hath fulfilled the law.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 33:8
verses.text: For this: Thou shalt not commit adultery, Thou shalt not kill, Thou shalt not steal, Thou shalt not covet; and if there be any other commandment, it is briefly comprehended in this saying, namely, Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 33:9
verses.text: Love worketh no ill to his neighbour: therefore love is the fulfilling of the law".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 33:10
verses.text: This love the Apostle Peter did not yet possess, when he for fear thrice denied the Lord.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 33:11
verses.text: "There is no fear in love," says the Evangelist John in his first Epistle, "but perfect love casteth out fear".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 33:12
verses.text: But yet, however small and imperfect his love was, it was not wholly wanting when he said to the Lord, "I will lay down my life for Thy sake;" for he supposed himself able to effect what he felt himself willing to do.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 33:13
verses.text: And who was it that had begun to give him his love, however small, but He who prepares the will, and perfects by His co-operation what He initiates by His operation? Forasmuch as in beginning He works in us that we may have the will, and in perfecting works with us when we have the will.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 33:14
verses.text: On which account the apostle says, "I am confident of this very thing, that He which hath begun a good work in you will perform it until the day of Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 33:15
verses.text: He operates, therefore, without us, in order that we may will; but when we will, and so will that we may act, He co-operates with us.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 33:16
verses.text: We can, however, ourselves do nothing to effect good works of piety without Him either working that we may will, or co-working when we will.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 33:17
verses.text: Now, concerning His working that we may will, it is said: "It is God which worketh in you, even to will".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 33:18
verses.text: While of His co-working with us, when we will and act by willing, the apostle says, "We know that in all things there is co-working for good to them that love God".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 33:19
verses.text: What does this phrase, "all things," mean, but the terrible and cruel sufferings which affect our condition? That burden, indeed, of Christ, which is heavy for our infirmity, becomes light to love.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 33:20
verses.text: For to such did the Lord say that His burden was light, as Peter was when he suffered for Christ, not as he was when he denied Him.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 34

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 34:1
verses.text: Chapter 34.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 34:2
verses.text: —The Apostle's Eulogy of Love.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 34:3
verses.text: Correction to Be Administered with Love.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 34:4
verses.text: This charity, that is, this will glowing with intensest love, the apostle eulogizes with these words: "Who shall separate us from the love of Christ? shall tribulation, or distress, or persecution, or famine, or nakedness, or peril, or the sword? (As it is written, For Thy sake we are killed all the day long; we are accounted as sheep for the slaughter.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 34:5
verses.text: ) Nay, in all these things we are more than conquerors, through Him that loved us.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 34:6
verses.text: For I am persuaded, that neither death, nor life, nor angels, nor principalities, nor things present, nor things to come, nor height, nor depth, nor any other creature, shall be able to separate us from the love of God, which is in Christ Jesus our Lord".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 34:7
verses.text: And in another passage he says, "And yet I show unto you a more excellent way.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 34:8
verses.text: Though I speak with the tongues of men and of angels, and have not love, I am become as sounding brass, or a tinkling cymbal.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 34:9
verses.text: And though I have the gift of prophecy, and understand all mysteries, and all knowledge; and though I have all faith, so that I could remove mountains, and have not love, I am nothing.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 34:10
verses.text: And though I bestow all my goods to feed the poor, and though I give my body to be burned, and have not love, it profiteth me nothing.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 34:11
verses.text: Love suffereth long, and is kind; love envieth not; love vaunteth not itself, is not puffed up, doth not behave itself unseemly, seeketh not her own, is not easily provoked, thinketh no evil; rejoiceth not in iniquity, but rejoiceth in the truth; beareth all things, believeth all things, hopeth all things, endureth all things.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 34:12
verses.text: Love never faileth".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 34:13
verses.text: And a little afterwards he says, "And now abideth faith, hope, love, these three; but the greatest of these is love.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 34:14
verses.text: Follow after love".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 34:15
verses.text: He also says to the Galatians, "For, brethren, ye have been called unto liberty; only use not liberty for an occasion to the flesh, but by love serve one another.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 34:16
verses.text: For all the law is fulfilled in one word, even in this, Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 34:17
verses.text: This is the same in effect as what he writes to the Romans: "He that loveth another hath fulfilled the law".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 34:18
verses.text: In like manner he says to the Colossians, "And above all these things, put on love, which is the bond of perfectness".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 34:19
verses.text: And to Timothy he writes, "Now the end of the commandment is love;" and he goes on to describe the quality of this grace, saying, "Out of a pure heart, and of a good conscience, and of faith unfeigned".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 34:20
verses.text: Moreover, when he says to the Corinthians, "Let all your things be done with love," he shows plainly enough that even those chastisements which are deemed sharp and bitter by those who are corrected thereby, are to be administered with love.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 34:21
verses.text: Accordingly, in another passage, after saying, "Warn them that are unruly, comfort the feeble-minded, support the weak, be patient toward all men," he immediately added, "See that none render evil for evil unto any man".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 34:22
verses.text: Therefore, even when the unruly are corrected, it is not rendering evil for evil, but contrariwise, good.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 34:23
verses.text: However, what but love worketh all these things?.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 35

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 35:1
verses.text: Chapter 35.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 35:2
verses.text: —Commendations of Love.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 35:3
verses.text: The Apostle Peter, likewise, says, "And, above all things, have fervent love among yourselves: for love shall cover the multitude of sins".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 35:4
verses.text: The Apostle James also says, "If ye fulfil the royal law, according to the Scripture, Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself, ye do well".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 35:5
verses.text: So also the Apostle John says, "He that loveth his brother abideth in the right;" again, in another passage, "Whosoever doeth not righteousness is not of God, neither he that loveth not his brother; for this is the message which we have heard from the beginning, that we should love one another".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 35:6
verses.text: Then he says again, "This is His commandment, that we should believe on the name of His Son Jesus Christ, and love one another".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 35:7
verses.text: Once more: "And this commandment have we from Him that he who loveth God love his brother also".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 35:8
verses.text: Then shortly afterwards he adds, "By this we know that we love the children of God, when we love God, and keep His commandments; for this is the love of God, that we keep His commandments: and His commandments are not grievous".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 35:9
verses.text: While, in his second Epistle, it is written, "Not as though I wrote a new commandment unto thee, but that which we had from the beginning, that we love one another".

chapters.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 36

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 36:1
verses.text: Chapter 36.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 36:2
verses.text: —Love Commended by Our Lord Himself.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 36:3
verses.text: Moreover, the Lord Jesus Himself teaches us that the whole law and the prophets hang upon the two precepts of love to God and love to our neighbour.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 36:4
verses.text: Concerning these two commandments the following is written in the Gospel according to St.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 36:5
verses.text: Mark: "And one of the scribes came, and having heard them reasoning together, and perceiving that He had answered them well, asked Him: Which is the first commandment of all? And Jesus answered him: The first of all the commandments is, Hear, O Israel! the Lord our God is one Lord; and thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thine heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy mind, and with all thy strength.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 36:6
verses.text: This is the first commandment.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 36:7
verses.text: And the second is like unto it: Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 36:8
verses.text: There is none other commandment greater than these".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 36:9
verses.text: Also, in the Gospel according to St.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 36:10
verses.text: John, He says, "A new commandment I give unto you, that ye love one another; as I have loved you, that ye also love one another.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 36:11
verses.text: By this shall all men know that ye are my disciples, if ye have love to one another".

chapters.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 37

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 37:1
verses.text: Chapter 37 (XVIII.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 37:2
verses.text: )—The Love Which Fulfils the Commandments is Not of Ourselves, But of God.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 37:3
verses.text: All these commandments, however, respecting love or charity (which are so great, and such that whatever action a man may think he does well is by no means well done if done without love) would be given to men in vain if they had not free choice of will.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 37:4
verses.text: But forasmuch as these precepts are given in the law, both old and new (although in the new came the grace which was promised in the old, but the law without grace is the letter which killeth, but in grace the Spirit which giveth life), from what source is there in men the love of God and of one's neighbour but from God Himself? For indeed, if it be not of God but of men, the Pelagians have gained the victory; but if it come from God, then we have vanquished the Pelagians.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 37:5
verses.text: Let, then, the Apostle John sit in judgment between us; and let him say to us, "Beloved, let us love one another".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 37:6
verses.text: Now, when they begin to extol themselves on these words of John, and to ask why this precept is addressed to us at all if we have not of our own selves to love one another, the same apostle proceeds at once, to their confusion, to add, "For love is of God".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 37:7
verses.text: It is not of ourselves, therefore, but it is of God.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 37:8
verses.text: Wherefore, then, is it said, "Let us love one another, for love is of God," unless it be as a precept to our free will, admonishing it to seek the gift of God? Now, this would be indeed a thoroughly fruitless admonition if the will did not previously receive some donation of love, which might seek to be enlarged so as to fulfil whatever command was laid upon it.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 37:9
verses.text: When it is said, "Let us love one another," it is law; when it is said, "For love is of God," it is grace.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 37:10
verses.text: For God's "wisdom carries law and mercy upon her tongue".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 37:11
verses.text: Accordingly, it is written in the Psalm, "For He who gave the law will give blessings".

chapters.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 38

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 38:1
verses.text: Chapter 38.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 38:2
verses.text: —We Would Not Love God Unless He First Loved Us.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 38:3
verses.text: The Apostles Chose Christ Because They Were Chosen; They Were Not Chosen Because They Chose Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 38:4
verses.text: Let no one, then, deceive you, my brethren, for we should not love God unless He first loved us.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 38:5
verses.text: John again gives us the plainest proof of this when he says, "We love Him because He first loved us".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 38:6
verses.text: Grace makes us lovers of the law; but the law itself, without grace, makes us nothing but breakers of the law.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 38:7
verses.text: And nothing else than this is shown us by the words of our Lord when He says to His disciples, Ye have not chosen me, but I have chosen you".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 38:8
verses.text: For if we first loved Him, in order that by this merit He might love us, then we first chose Him that we might deserve to be chosen by Him.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 38:9
verses.text: He, however, who is the Truth says otherwise, and flatly contradicts this vain conceit of men.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 38:10
verses.text: "You have not chosen me," He says.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 38:11
verses.text: If, therefore, you have not chosen me, undoubtedly you have not loved me (for how could they choose one whom they did not love?).

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 38:12
verses.text: "But I," says He, "have chosen you".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 38:13
verses.text: And then could they possibly help choosing Him afterwards, and preferring Him to all the blessings of this world? But it was because they had been chosen, that they chose Him; not because they chose Him that they were chosen.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 38:14
verses.text: There could be no merit in men's choice of Christ, if it were not that God's grace was prevenient in His choosing them.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 38:15
verses.text: Whence the Apostle Paul pronounces in the Thessalonians this benediction: "The Lord make you to increase and abound in love one toward another, and toward all men".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 38:16
verses.text: This benediction to love one another He gave us, who had also given us a law that we should love each other.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 38:17
verses.text: Then, in another passage addressed to the same church, seeing that there now existed in some of its members the disposition which he had wished them to cultivate, he says, "We are bound to thank God always for you, brethren, as it is meet, because that your faith groweth exceedingly, and the charity of every one of you all toward each other aboundeth".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 38:18
verses.text: This he said lest they should make a boast of the great good which they were enjoying from God, as if they had it of their own mere selves.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 38:19
verses.text: Because, then, your faith has so great a growth (this is the purport of his words), and the love of every one of you all toward each other so greatly abounds, we ought to thank God concerning you, but not to praise you, as if you possessed these gifts of yourselves.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 39

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 39:1
verses.text: Chapter 39.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 39:2
verses.text: —The Spirit of Fear a Great Gift of God.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 39:3
verses.text: The apostle also says to Timothy, "For God hath not given to us the spirit of fear, but of power, and of love, and of a sound mind".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 39:4
verses.text: Now in respect of this passage of the apostle, we must be on our guard against supposing that we have not received the spirit of the fear of God, which is undoubtedly a great gift of God, and concerning which the prophet Isaiah says, "The Spirit of the Lord shall rest upon thee, the spirit of wisdom and understanding, the spirit of counsel and might, the spirit of knowledge and piety, the spirit of the fear of the Lord".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 39:5
verses.text: It is not the fear with which Peter denied Christ that we have received the spirit of, but that fear concerning which Christ Himself says, "Fear Him who hath power to destroy both soul and body in hell; yea, I say unto you, Fear Him".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 39:6
verses.text: This, indeed, He said, lest we should deny Him from the same fear which shook Peter; for such cowardice he plainly wished to be removed from us when He, in the preceding passage, said, "Be not afraid of them that kill the body, and after that have no more that they can do".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 39:7
verses.text: It is not of this fear that we have received the spirit, but of power, and of love, and of a sound mind.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 39:8
verses.text: And of this spirit the same Apostle Paul discourses to the Romans: "We glory in tribulations, knowing that tribulation worketh patience; and patience, experience; and experience, hope; and hope maketh not ashamed; because the love of God is shed abroad in our hearts by the Holy Ghost, which is given unto us".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 39:9
verses.text: Not by ourselves, therefore, but by the Holy Ghost which is given to us, does it come to pass that, through that very love, which he shows us to be the gift of God, tribulation does not do away with patience, but rather produces it.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 39:10
verses.text: Again, he says to the Ephesians, "Peace be to the brethren, and love with faith".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 39:11
verses.text: Great blessings these! Let him tell us, however, whence they come.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 39:12
verses.text: "From God the Father," says he immediately afterwards, "and the Lord Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 39:13
verses.text: These great blessings, therefore, are nothing else than God's gifts to us.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 40

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 40:1
verses.text: Chapter 40 (XIX.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 40:2
verses.text: )—The Ignorance of the Pelagians in Maintaining that the Knowledge of the Law Comes from God, But that Love Comes from Ourselves.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 40:3
verses.text: It is no wonder that light shineth in darkness, and the darkness comprehendeth it not.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 40:4
verses.text: In John's Epistle the Light declares, "Behold what manner of love the Father hath bestowed upon us, that we should be called the sons of God".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 40:5
verses.text: And in the Pelagian writings the darkness says, "Love comes to us of our own selves".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 40:6
verses.text: Now, if they only possessed the true, that is, Christian love, they would also know whence they obtained possession of it; even as the apostle knew when he said, "But we have received not the spirit of the world, but the Spirit which is of God, that we might know the things that are freely given to us of God".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 40:7
verses.text: John says, "God is love".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 40:8
verses.text: And thus the Pelagians affirm that they actually have God Himself, not from God, but from their own selves! and although they allow that we have the knowledge of the law from God, they will yet have it that love is from our very selves.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 40:9
verses.text: Nor do they listen to the apostle when he says, "Knowledge puffeth up, but love edifieth".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 40:10
verses.text: Now what can be more absurd, nay, what more insane and more alien from the very sacredness of love itself, than to maintain that from God proceeds the knowledge which, apart from love, puffs us up, while the love which prevents the possibility of this inflation of knowledge springs from ourselves? And again, when the apostle speaks of "the love of Christ as surpassing knowledge," what can be more insane than to suppose that the knowledge which must be subordinated to love comes from God, while the love which surpasses knowledge comes from man? The true faith, however, and sound doctrine declare that both graces are from God; the Scripture says, "From His face cometh knowledge and understanding;" and another Scripture says, "Love is of God".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 40:11
verses.text: We read of "the Spirit of wisdom and understanding".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 40:12
verses.text: Also of "the Spirit of power, and of love, and of a sound mind".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 40:13
verses.text: But love is a greater gift than knowledge; for whenever a man has the gift of knowledge, love is necessary by the side of it, that he be not puffed up.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 40:14
verses.text: For "love envieth not, vaunteth not itself, is not puffed up".

chapters.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 41

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 41:1
verses.text: Chapter 41 (XX.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 41:2
verses.text: )—The Wills of Men are So Much in the Power of God, that He Can Turn Them Whithersoever It Pleases Him.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 41:3
verses.text: I think I have now discussed the point fully enough in opposition to those who vehemently oppose the grace of God, by which, however, the human will is not taken away, but changed from bad to good, and assisted when it is good.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 41:4
verses.text: I think, too, that I have so discussed the subject, that it is not so much I myself as the inspired Scripture which has spoken to you, in the clearest testimonies of truth; and if this divine record be looked into carefully, it shows us that not only men's good wills, which God Himself converts from bad ones, and, when converted by Him, directs to good actions and to eternal life, but also those which follow the world are so entirely at the disposal of God, that He turns them whithersoever He wills, and whensoever He wills,—to bestow kindness on some, and to heap punishment on others, as He Himself judges right by a counsel most secret to Himself, indeed, but beyond all doubt most righteous.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 41:5
verses.text: For we find that some sins are even the punishment of other sins, as are those "vessels of wrath" which the apostle describes as "fitted to destruction;" as is also that hardening of Pharaoh, the purpose of which is said to be to set forth in him the power of God; as, again, is the flight of the Israelites from the face of the enemy before the city of Ai, for fear arose in their heart so that they fled, and this was done that their sin might be punished in the way it was right that it should be; by reason of which the Lord said to Joshua the son of Nun, "The children of Israel shall not be able to stand before the face of their enemies".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 41:6
verses.text: What is the meaning of, "They shall not be able to stand"? Now, why did they not stand by free will, but, with a will perplexed by fear, took to flight, were it not that God has the lordship even over men's wills, and when He is angry turns to fear whomsoever He pleases? Was it not of their own will that the enemies of the children of Israel fought against the people of God, as led by Joshua, the son of Nun? And yet the Scripture says, "It was of the Lord to harden their hearts, that they should come against Israel in battle, that they might be exterminated".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 41:7
verses.text: And was it not likewise of his own will that the wicked son of Gera cursed King David? And yet what says David, full of true, and deep, and pious wisdom? What did he say to him who wanted to smite the reviler? "What," said he, "have I to do with you, ye sons of Zeruiah? Let him alone and let him curse, because the Lord hath said unto him, Curse David.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 41:8
verses.text: Who, then, shall say, Wherefore hast thou done so?" And then the inspired Scripture, as if it would confirm the king's profound utterance by repeating it once more, tells us: "And David said to Abishai, and to all his servants, Behold, my son, which came forth from my bowels, seeketh my life: how much more may this Benjamite do it! Let him alone, and let him curse; for the Lord hath bidden him.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 41:9
verses.text: It may be that the Lord will look on my humiliation, and will requite me good for his cursing this day".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 41:10
verses.text: Now what prudent reader will fail to understand in what way the Lord bade this profane man to curse David? It was not by a command that He bade him, in which case his obedience would be praiseworthy; but He inclined the man's will, which had become debased by his own perverseness, to commit this sin, by His own just and secret judgment.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 41:11
verses.text: Therefore it is said, "The Lord said unto him".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 41:12
verses.text: Now if this person had obeyed a command of God, he would have deserved to be praised rather than punished, as we know he was afterwards punished for this sin.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 41:13
verses.text: Nor is the reason an obscure one why the Lord told him after this manner to curse David.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 41:14
verses.text: "It may be," said the humbled king, "that the Lord will look on my humiliation, and will requite me good for his cursing this day".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 41:15
verses.text: See, then, what proof we have here that God uses the hearts of even wicked men for the praise and assistance of the good.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 41:16
verses.text: Thus did He make use of Judas when betraying Christ; thus did He make use of the Jews when they crucified Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 41:17
verses.text: And how vast the blessings which from these instances He has bestowed upon the nations that should believe in Him! He also uses our worst enemy, the devil himself, but in the best way, to exercise and try the faith and piety of good men,—not for Himself indeed, who knows all things before they come to pass, but for our sakes, for whom it was necessary that such a discipline should be gone through with us.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 41:18
verses.text: Did not Absalom choose by his own will the counsel which was detrimental to him? And yet the reason of his doing so was that the Lord had heard his father's prayer that it might be so.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 41:19
verses.text: Wherefore the Scripture says that "the Lord appointed to defeat the good counsel of Ahithophel, to the intent that the Lord might bring all evils upon Absalom".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 41:20
verses.text: It called Ahithophel's counsel "good," because it was for the moment of advantage to his purpose.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 41:21
verses.text: It was in favour of the son against his father, against whom he had rebelled; and it might have crushed him, had not the Lord defeated the counsel which Ahithophel had given, by acting on the heart of Absalom so that he rejected this counsel, and chose another which was not expedient for him.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 42

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 42:1
verses.text: Chapter 42 (XXI)—God Does Whatsoever He Wills in the Hearts of Even Wicked Men.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 42:2
verses.text: Who can help trembling at those judgments of God by which He does in the hearts of even wicked men whatsoever He wills, at the same time rendering to them according to their deeds? Rehoboam, the son of Solomon, rejected the salutary counsel of the old men, not to deal harshly with the people, and preferred listening to the words of the young men of his own age, by returning a rough answer to those to whom he should have spoken gently.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 42:3
verses.text: Now whence arose such conduct, except from his own will? Upon this, however, the ten tribes of Israel revolted from him, and chose for themselves another king, even Jeroboam, that the will of God in His anger might be accomplished which He had predicted would come to pass.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 42:4
verses.text: For what says the Scripture? "The king hearkened not unto the people; for the turning was from the Lord, that He might perform His saying, which the Lord spake to Ahijah the Shilonite concerning Jeroboam the son of Nebat".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 42:5
verses.text: All this, indeed, was done by the will of man, although the turning was from the Lord.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 42:6
verses.text: Read the books of the Chronicles, and you will find the following passage in the second book: "Moreover, the Lord stirred up against Jehoram the spirit of the Philistines, and of the Arabians, that were neighbours to the Ethiopians; and they came up to the land of Judah, and ravaged it, and carried away all the substance which was found in the king's house".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 42:7
verses.text: Here it is shown that God stirs up enemies to devastate the countries which He adjudges deserving of such chastisement.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 42:8
verses.text: Still, did these Philistines and Arabians invade the land of Judah to waste it with no will of their own? Or were their movements so directed by their own will that the Scripture lies which tells us that "the Lord stirred up their spirit" to do all this? Both statements to be sure are true, because they both came by their own will, and yet the Lord stirred up their spirit; and this may also with equal truth be stated the other way: The Lord both stirred up their spirit, and yet they came of their own will.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 42:9
verses.text: For the Almighty sets in motion even in the innermost hearts of men the movement of their will, so that He does through their agency whatsoever He wishes to perform through them,—even He who knows not how to will anything in unrighteousness.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 42:10
verses.text: What, again, is the purport of that which the man of God said to King Amaziah: "Let not the army of Israel go with thee; for the Lord is not with Israel, even with all the children of Ephraim: for if thou shalt think to obtain with these, the Lord shall put thee to flight before thine enemies: for God hath power either to strengthen or to put to flight"? Now, how does the power of God help some in war by giving them confidence, and put others to flight by injecting fear into them, except it be that He who has made all things according to His own will, in heaven and on earth, also works in the hearts of men? We read also what Joash, king of Israel, said when he sent a message to Amaziah, king of Judah, who wanted to fight with him.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 42:11
verses.text: After certain other words, he added, "Now tarry at home; why dost thou challenge me to thine hurt, that thou shouldest fall, even thou, and Judah with thee?" Then the Scripture has added this sequel: "But Amaziah would not hear; for it came of God, that he might be delivered into their hands, because they sought after the gods of Edom".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 42:12
verses.text: Behold, now, how God, wishing to punish the sin of idolatry, wrought this in this man's heart, with whom He was indeed justly angry, not to listen to sound advice, but to despise it, and go to the battle, in which he with his army was routed.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 42:13
verses.text: God says by the prophet Ezekiel, "If the prophet be deceived when he hath spoken a thing, I the Lord have deceived that prophet: I will stretch out my hand upon him, and will destroy him from the midst of my people Israel".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 42:14
verses.text: Then there is the book of Esther, who was a woman of the people of Israel, and in the land of their captivity became the wife of the foreign King Ahasuerus.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 42:15
verses.text: In this book it is written, that, being driven by necessity to interpose in behalf of her people, whom the king had ordered to be slain in every part of his dominions, she prayed to the Lord.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 42:16
verses.text: So strongly was she urged by the necessity of the case, that she even ventured into the royal presence without the king's command, and contrary to her own custom.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 42:17
verses.text: Now observe what the Scripture says: "He looked at her like a bull in the vehemence of his indignation; and the queen was afraid, and her colour changed as she fainted; and she bowed herself upon the head of her delicate maiden which went before her.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 42:18
verses.text: But God turned the king, and transformed his indignation into gentleness".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 42:19
verses.text: The Scripture says in the Proverbs of Solomon, "Even as the rush of water, so is the heart of a king in God's hand; He will turn it in whatever way He shall choose".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 42:20
verses.text: Again, in the 104th Psalm, in reference to the Egyptians, one reads what God did to them: "And He turned their heart to hate His people, to deal subtilly with His servants".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 42:21
verses.text: Observe, likewise, what is written in the letters of the apostles.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 42:22
verses.text: In the Epistle of Paul, the Apostle, to the Romans occur these words: "Wherefore God gave them up to uncleanness, through the lusts of their own hearts;" and a little afterwards: "For this cause God gave them up unto vile affections;" again, in the next passage: "And even as they did not like to retain God in their knowledge, God gave them over to a reprobate mind, to do those things which are not convenient".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 42:23
verses.text: So also in his second Epistle to the Thessalonians, the apostle says of sundry persons, "Inasmuch as they received not the love of the truth, that they might be saved; therefore also God shall send them strong delusion, that they should believe a lie; that they all might be judged who believed not the truth, but had pleasure in unrighteousness".

chapters.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 43

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 43:1
verses.text: Chapter 43.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 43:2
verses.text: —God Operates on Men's Hearts to Incline Their Wills Whithersoever He Pleases.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 43:3
verses.text: From these statements of the inspired word, and from similar passages which it would take too long to quote in full, it is, I think, sufficiently clear that God works in the hearts of men to incline their wills whithersoever He wills, whether to good deeds according to His mercy, or to evil after their own deserts; His own judgment being sometimes manifest, sometimes secret, but always righteous.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 43:4
verses.text: This ought to be the fixed and immoveable conviction of your heart, that there is no unrighteousness with God.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 43:5
verses.text: Therefore, whenever you read in the Scriptures of Truth, that men are led aside, or that their hearts are blunted and hardened by God, never doubt that some ill deserts of their own have first occurred, so that they justly suffer these things.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 43:6
verses.text: Thus you will not run counter to that proverb of Solomon: "The foolishness of a man perverteth his ways, yet he blameth God in his heart".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 43:7
verses.text: Grace, however, is not bestowed according to men's deserts; otherwise grace would be no longer grace.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 43:8
verses.text: For grace is so designated because it is given gratuitously.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 43:9
verses.text: Now if God is able, either through the agency of angels (whether good ones or evil), or in any other way whatever, to operate in the hearts even of the wicked, in return for their deserts,—whose wickedness was not made by Him, but was either derived originally from Adam, or increased by their own will,—what is there to wonder at if, through the Holy Spirit, He works good in the hearts of the elect, who has wrought it that their hearts become good instead of evil?.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 44

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 44:1
verses.text: Chapter 44 (XXII.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 44:2
verses.text: )—Gratuitous Grace Exemplified in Infants.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 44:3
verses.text: Men, however, may suppose that there are certain good deserts which they think are precedent to justification through God's grace; all the while failing to see, when they express such an opinion, that they do nothing else than deny grace.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 44:4
verses.text: But, as I have already remarked, let them suppose what they like respecting the case of adults, in the case of infants, at any rate, the Pelagians find no means of answering the difficulty.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 44:5
verses.text: For these in receiving grace have no will; from the influence of which they can pretend to any precedent merit.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 44:6
verses.text: We see, moreover, how they cry and struggle when they are baptized, and feel the divine sacraments.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 44:7
verses.text: Such conduct would, of course, be charged against them as a great impiety, if they already had free will in use; and notwithstanding this, grace cleaves to them even in their resisting struggles.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 44:8
verses.text: But most certainly there is no prevenient merit, otherwise the grace would be no longer grace.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 44:9
verses.text: Sometimes, too, this grace is bestowed upon the children of unbelievers, when they happen by some means or other to fall, by reason of God's secret providence, into the hands of pious persons; but, on the other hand, the children of believers fail to obtain grace, some hindrance occurring to prevent the approach of help to rescue them in their danger.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 44:10
verses.text: These things, no doubt, happen through the secret providence of God, whose judgments are unsearchable, and His ways past finding out.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 44:11
verses.text: These are the words of the apostle; and you should observe what he had previously said, to lead him to add such a remark.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 44:12
verses.text: He was discoursing about the Jews and Gentiles, when he wrote to the Romans—themselves Gentiles—to this effect: "For as ye, in times past, have not believed God, yet have now obtained mercy through their unbelief; even so have these also now not believed, that through your mercy they also may obtain mercy; for God hath concluded them all in unbelief, that He might have mercy upon all".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 44:13
verses.text: Now, after he had thought upon what he said, full of wonder at the certain truth of his own assertion, indeed, but astonished at its great depth, how God concluded all in unbelief that He might have mercy upon all,—as if doing evil that good might come,—he at once exclaimed, and said, "O the depth of the riches both of the wisdom and knowledge of God! how unsearchable are His judgments, and His ways past finding out!" Perverse men, who do not reflect upon these unsearchable judgments and untraceable ways, indeed, but are ever prone to censure, being unable to understand, have supposed the apostle to say, and censoriously gloried over him for saying, "Let us do evil, that good may come!" God forbid that the apostle should say so! But men, without understanding, have thought that this was in fact said, when they heard these words of the apostle: "Moreover, the law entered, that the offence might abound; but where sin abounded, grace did much more abound".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 44:14
verses.text: But grace, indeed, effects this purpose—that good works should now be wrought by those who previously did evil; not that they should persevere in evil courses and suppose that they are recompensed with good.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 44:15
verses.text: Their language, therefore, ought not to be: "Let us do evil, that good may come;" but: "We have done evil, and good has come; let us henceforth do good, that in the future world we may receive good for good, who in the present life are receiving good for evil".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 44:16
verses.text: Wherefore it is written in the Psalm, "I will sing of mercy and judgment unto Thee, O Lord".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 44:17
verses.text: When the Son of man, therefore, first came into the world, it was not to judge the world, but that the world through Him might be saved.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 44:18
verses.text: And this dispensation was for mercy; by and by, however, He will come for judgment—to judge the quick and the dead.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 44:19
verses.text: And yet even in this present time salvation itself does not eventuate without judgment—although it be a hidden one; therefore He says, "For judgment I am come into this world, that they which see not may see, and that they which see may be made blind".

chapters.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 45

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 45:1
verses.text: Chapter 45 (XXIII)—The Reason Why One Person is Assisted by Grace, and Another is Not Helped, Must Be Referred to the Secret Judgments of God.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 45:2
verses.text: You must refer the matter, then, to the hidden determinations of God, when you see, in one and the same condition, such as all infants unquestionably have,—who derive their hereditary evil from Adam,—that one is assisted so as to be baptized, and another is not assisted, so that he dies in his very bondage; and again, that one baptized person is left and forsaken in his present life, who God foreknew would be ungodly, while another baptized person is taken away from this life, "lest that wickedness should alter his understanding;" and be sure that you do not in such cases ascribe unrighteousness or unwisdom to God, in whom is the very fountain of righteousness and wisdom, but, as I have exhorted you from the commencement of this treatise, "whereto you have already attained, walk therein," and "even this shall God reveal unto you,"—if not in this life, yet certainly in the next, "for there is nothing covered that shall not be revealed".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 45:3
verses.text: When, therefore, you hear the Lord say, "I the Lord have deceived that prophet," and likewise what the apostle says: "He hath mercy on whom He will have mercy, and whom He will He hardeneth," believe that, in the case of him whom He permits to be deceived and hardened, his evil deeds have deserved the judgment; whilst in the case of him to whom He shows mercy, you should loyally and unhesitatingly recognise the grace of the God who "rendereth not evil for evil; but contrariwise blessing".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 45:4
verses.text: Nor should you take away from Pharaoh free will, because in several passages God says, "I have hardened Pharaoh;" or," I have hardened or I will harden Pharaoh's heart;" for it does not by any means follow that Pharaoh did not, on this account, harden his own heart.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 45:5
verses.text: For this, too, is said of him, after the removal of the fly-plague from the Egyptians, in these words of the Scripture: "And Pharaoh hardened his heart at this time also; neither would he let the people go".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 45:6
verses.text: Thus it was that both God hardened him by His just judgment, and Pharaoh by his own free will.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 45:7
verses.text: Be ye then well assured that your labour will never be in vain, if, setting before you a good purpose, you persevere in it to the last.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 45:8
verses.text: For God, who fails to render, according to their deeds, only to those whom He liberates, will then "recompense every man according to his works".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 45:9
verses.text: God will, therefore, certainly recompense both evil for evil, because He is just; and good for evil, because He is good; and good for good, because He is good and just; only, evil for good He will never recompense, because He is not unjust.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 45:10
verses.text: He will, therefore, recompense evil for evil—punishment for unrighteousness; and He will recompense good for evil—grace for unrighteousness; and He will recompense good for good—grace for grace.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 46

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 46:1
verses.text: Chapter 46 (XXIV.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 46:2
verses.text: )—Understanding and Wisdom Must Be Sought from God.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 46:3
verses.text: Peruse attentively this treatise, and if you understand it, give God the praise; but where you fail to understand it, pray for understanding, for God will give you understanding.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 46:4
verses.text: Remember what the Scriptures say: "If any of you lack wisdom, let him ask of God, who giveth to all men liberally, and upbraideth not; and it shall be given to him".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 46:5
verses.text: Wisdom itself cometh down from above, as the Apostle James himself tells us.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 46:6
verses.text: There is, however, another wisdom, which you must repel from you, and pray against its remaining in you; this the same apostle expressed his detestation of when he said, "But if ye have bitter envying and strife in your hearts,.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 46:7
verses.text: this is not the wisdom which descendeth from above, but is earthly, sensual, devilish.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 46:8
verses.text: For wherever there is envying and strife, there is also confusion, and every evil work.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 46:9
verses.text: But the wisdom which is from above is first pure, then peaceable, gentle, and easy to be entreated, full of mercy and good works, without partiality, and without hypocrisy".

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 46:10
verses.text: What blessing, then, will that man not have who has prayed for this wisdom and obtained it of the Lord? And from this you may understand what grace is; because if this wisdom were of ourselves, it would not be from above; nor would it be an object to be asked for of the God who created us.

verses.name: Augustine: On Grace and Free Will 46:11
verses.text: Brethren, pray ye for us also, that we may live "soberly, righteously, and godly in this present world; looking for that blessed hope, and the glorious appearing of our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ," to whom belong the honour, and the glory, and the kingdom, with the Father and the Holy Ghost, for ever and ever, Amen.
